frameDefinitions: Item-1 and Item-2 are compatible with each other if they can exist or function together in some context without problems, conflict, or other undesirable situation.
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
This frame has to do with the bias or lack of bias of a Judge making an assessment concerning two or more Sides.
A Cognizer decides upon the Chosen (either an item or a course of action) out of a set of  Possibilities .
An Experiencer has a greater desire to participate in some Event, as against another (contextually recoverable) event which exhibits a specific Contrast with the Event.
Two or more distinct entities, which may be concrete or abstract objects or types, are characterized as being similar to each other.
frameExamples: Make sure your site is <t>compatible</t> with any browser.
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
The council <t>picked</t> you out of all the pilots available to head this mission.

A mulberry is very <t>similar</t> in shape
to a loganberry
listRoleDefinitions: The Frame Element <fen>Item_1</fen> marks the grammatically more prominent of the two entities, i.e.the subject in active clauses, when they are expressed separately.
The Frame Element <fen>Item_2</fen> marks the grammatically less prominent of the <fen>Items</fen> when they are expressed separately.
This role is used when the <fen>Items</fen> are expressed jointly in a phrase, either a plural or a coordinated NP.
This Frame Element is used for expressions that indicate a <fen>Parameter</fen> or respect in which the <fen>Items</fen> are said to be compatible, not in conflict.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
This Frame Element marks the person whose objectivity in making assesment is being evaluated.
This Frame Element marks one of the <fen>Sides</fen> in a dispute or one of the alternatives in a situation of choice.
This Frame Element marks phrases jointly expressing both <fen>Sides</fen> in a dispute or all of the alternatives in a situation of choice.
The second-mentioned of the <fen>Sides</fen> to a dispute or alternatives in a situation of choice.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate how the bias of the <fen>Judge</fen> expresses itself in their behavior or actions.
The <fen>Dispute</fen> is the situation in which there is some conflict between two sides.
The individual whose point of view is taken in assigning the judgment denoted by the target.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part which indicates the character of the <fen>Decision_maker</fen>.
This role denotes the time when the partiality occurs.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> chooses the <fen>Chosen</fen> out of the <fen>Possibilities</fen>.
<fen>Chosen</fen> identifies the entity or course of action which is selected from among the <fen>Possibilities</fen>.

A <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes a choice from among a set of <fen>Possibilities</fen>. <fen>Possibilities</fen> are commonly expressed via an oblique phrase which indicates the alternative or alternatives, or by a subordinate clause (choosing to do it or choosing not to do it), typically headed by 'whether or 'if'.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> chooses the <fen>Chosen</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the choosing occurs.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person (or sentient being) who wishes for the <fen>Event</fen> to occur.
The change that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> would like to see.
This is the entity that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> wishes to be affected by some <fen>Event</fen>.
The <fen>Location_of_event</fen> is the place involved in the desired <fen>Event</fen>.
An alternative <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Focal_participant</fen> that is less desirable for the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Experiencer</fen> desires something.
Where the event takes place.  Note that this role is of extremely rare occurrence in this frame.
This role marks constituents that express the set of objects or types whose similarity is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the entity characterized by its similarity to <fen>Entity_2</fen>, whose characteristics are assumed to be known.  <fen>Entity_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Entities</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Entity_2</fen> is the one whose characteristics are assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing characteristics of <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
This role marks constituents which express a property in respect to which the similarity of the entities is assessed.
A fact about <fen>Entity_1</fen> or the <fen>Entities</fen> that reveals how <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the same or different from other entities.  (Note the contrast with 'as to'.)
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the similarity occurs or exists.
The Place is the general area in which similarity occurs or exists
listRoleExamples: <fex>That technology</fex> turned out not to be compatible with the existing devices
My computer is not compatible <fex>with my new printer</fex>.
<fex>Your socks</fex> don't match.
The two applications are compatible <fex>in their essential features</fex>.
Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
<fex>The referee</fex> was totally biased against our team.
The umpire was partial <fex>to the home team</fex>.
The judge was neutral <fex>between the parties</fex>.
The judge favored the defendant <fex>over the plaintiff</fex>.
The judge made a biased <fex>decision</fex>.
My sister remained neutral <fex>in our disputes</fex>.
He had a neutral <fex>smile</fex> on his face.
<fex>We</fex>have to pick a colour for the living room.
I decided <fex>to give it another try</fex>.
They chose their new guitarist <fex>out of more than 300 auditioners</fex>.
I was n't chosen <fex>in the last round</fex>.
The winner was selected <fex>in the secret meeting room</fex>.
I always preferred trackballs <fex>over mouses</fex>.
<fex>The two painters</fex> were alike in being unable to draw acceptably .
In the first phase <fex>Barthes's approach</fex> has similarities to that of Levi-Strauss.
The results of Method 2 show remarkable similarity <fex>to those obtained by Method 1</fex>
The disc announced Friday is <fex>physically</fex> similar to current music CDs
His presidency was different <fex>in that it offered a way forward for the common man</fex> .
